systems.name: Alde Wet Heating System
systems.description: The Ixeo I 744 features an Alde wet (hydronic) heating system that uses a glycol fluid circuit to distribute heat via radiators and underfloor heating. It can operate on gas, 230V mains electricity, or a combination of both. The system also provides domestic hot water.

images.caption: Alde control panel - select heating mode and set temperature
Alde boiler location - usually under a seat or bed
Radiator convectors distribute heat throughout the vehicle

safety_notes: Never run gas heating while refuelling at petrol stations
Ensure adequate ventilation when heating is in use
Check glycol fluid levels annually - use only Alde-approved fluid
Do not block radiator convectors or underfloor heating vents
Allow system to cool before checking fluid level
If you smell gas, turn off immediately and ventilate

systems.name: 3-Way Fridge
systems.description: The 3-way absorption fridge can operate on 12V DC (while driving), 230V AC (on mains hook-up), or gas (for off-grid use). The fridge automatically selects the power source or can be manually set. Always level the vehicle for optimal cooling performance.

images.caption: 3-way fridge interior with adjustable shelves

images.alt: Fridge control panel showing mode selection
images.caption: Fridge controls - select 12V, 230V, gas, or auto mode

images.alt: External fridge vent on vehicle side
images.caption: External fridge vent - ensure it is not blocked

safety_notes: Switch fridge to 12V mode before driving if not automatic
Turn off gas supply to fridge before refuelling
Ensure external vents are not blocked for proper cooling
Level the vehicle within 3 degrees for efficient operation
Do not leave fridge on gas while vehicle is in motion
Allow 24 hours for fridge to reach optimal temperature

systems.name: Solar Charging System
systems.description: The roof-mounted solar panel system charges the leisure battery first, then the vehicle battery when the leisure battery is full. This provides silent, free charging when parked, extending off-grid capability.

images.alt: Solar panel mounted on vehicle roof
images.caption: Roof-mounted solar panel
Solar controller showing charge status and output
Leisure battery - solar charges this first

safety_notes: Do not walk on solar panels
Keep panels clean for optimal charging efficiency
Check controller display for charging status
Solar charging is automatic - no action required
In prolonged shade, connect to mains to maintain battery charge

systems.name: 360° Surround Camera
systems.description: The 360-degree surround camera system provides a bird's-eye view of the vehicle and surroundings, displayed on the dashboard monitor. Useful for manoeuvring in tight spaces, checking clearances, and parking.

images.caption: 360° view displayed on dashboard monitor
Front camera mounted on the grille area
Side cameras under wing mirrors

safety_notes: Always perform visual checks in addition to using cameras
Keep camera lenses clean for clear images
Camera view may be limited in poor lighting conditions
Do not rely solely on cameras - use mirrors and direct observation
Check display before moving in any direction

systems.name: Reversing Camera
systems.description: The rear-mounted reversing camera automatically activates when reverse gear is selected, displaying a live image on the dashboard monitor with guidance lines to assist with parking and manoeuvring.

images.alt: Dashboard display showing reversing camera view
images.caption: Reversing camera view with parking guidelines

images.alt: Rear camera mounted above number plate
images.caption: Rear camera location above the number plate

safety_notes: Camera activates automatically when reverse is selected
Use mirrors and direct checks as well as the camera
Keep camera lens clean for clear visibility
Be aware of blind spots not covered by the camera
Check for children, pets, and low obstacles before reversing

systems.name: Front Cab Avtex TV
systems.description: The Avtex TV in the front cab area is designed for motorhome use with 12V and 240V operation. It includes built-in Freeview tuner and DVD player. The swivel mount allows viewing from cab seats when parked.

images.alt: Avtex TV mounted in front cab
images.caption: Front cab TV with swivel mount
Avtex remote control

safety_notes: Do not watch TV while driving
Secure TV in stowed position before driving
Only use on 12V when parked to avoid battery drain
Extend aerial for best reception
Check TV is secure before travelling

systems.name: Rear Lounge Avtex TV
systems.description: A second Avtex TV is mounted in the rear lounge area for entertainment while relaxing or in bed. Like the front TV, it operates on both 12V and 240V with built-in tuner and media capabilities.

images.alt: Avtex TV mounted in rear lounge
images.caption: Rear lounge TV viewing position
Rear TV bracket and connections

safety_notes: Secure TV before driving
Do not block ventilation around TV
Monitor battery level when using on 12V
Extend the aerial before use for best reception

systems.name: Electric Drop-Down Bed (Rear Lounge)
systems.description: The electric drop-down bed above the rear lounge area can be lowered to provide a double sleeping space. Controlled by a wall-mounted switch, it lowers smoothly and can be stopped at any height.

images.alt: Rear drop-down bed in raised position
images.caption: Drop-down bed stored in raised position

images.alt: Rear drop-down bed lowered for sleeping
images.caption: Bed lowered - ready for sleeping
Hold button to lower or raise the bed

safety_notes: Ensure bed is FULLY raised and secured before driving
Clear the area below before lowering the bed
Do not exceed bed weight limit
Keep fingers clear of mechanism during operation
Do not use bed controls while driving

systems.name: Pull-Down Bed (Half Dinette)
systems.description: A pull-down bed above the half dinette provides additional sleeping accommodation. This bed folds down manually from the ceiling area and is secured with straps or latches when not in use.

images.alt: Pull-down bed in stowed position above dinette
images.caption: Bed stowed flush against ceiling
Bed pulled down and ready for use
Latch releases the bed for deployment

safety_notes: Ensure bed is securely latched before driving
Check support straps are in good condition
Clear the dinette area before deploying bed
Do not exceed weight limit
Verify latches are fully engaged when stowed

systems.name: Blinds and Flyscreens
systems.description: All windows and skylights are fitted with integrated blinds and flyscreens. The cassette blinds provide privacy and blackout capability, while the flyscreens allow ventilation while keeping insects out.

images.caption: Cassette blind for privacy and blackout
Flyscreen allows ventilation without insects
Skylight with blind and flyscreen

safety_notes: Close blinds and secure roof skylights before driving
Do not force blind mechanisms
Clean flyscreens gently to avoid damage
Report any stuck or damaged blinds for repair

systems.name: External Silver Front Heat Shield
systems.description: The external silver heat shield covers the front windscreen and cab windows to reflect sunlight and insulate against temperature extremes. It helps keep the cab cool in summer and warm in winter.

images.alt: Heat shield fitted to front of motorhome
images.caption: Silver heat shield installed on cab
Fold and store when not in use

safety_notes: Remove heat shield completely before driving
Store securely to prevent it blowing away
Check straps and suction cups regularly
Clean occasionally to maintain reflectivity

systems.name: Awning
systems.description: The vehicle-mounted awning extends from the side to provide shade and weather protection. It is manually operated with a winding handle and can be secured with ground pegs or weights in windy conditions.

images.alt: Awning fully extended from vehicle side
images.caption: Awning extended providing outdoor shade
Use winding handle to extend/retract awning
Secure legs with pegs in windy conditions

safety_notes: Never drive with awning extended
Retract awning in strong winds
Secure legs with pegs or weights
Do not allow water to pool on awning fabric
Dry awning before storage to prevent mould

systems.name: Outdoor Shower
systems.description: An external shower point provides hot and cold water access outside the vehicle, useful for rinsing off after beach visits, cleaning equipment, or showering outdoors in warm weather.

images.caption: Outdoor shower connection behind panel
Connect shower head for outdoor use

safety_notes: Check water temperature before use - can be very hot
Ensure adequate water in tank before extended use
Grey water will drain to ground - use in appropriate locations
Drain and close securely after use to prevent freezing

systems.name: Outdoor Gas BBQ Point
systems.description: An external gas point allows connection of a portable BBQ or outdoor cooking equipment. The gas supply is connected to the onboard gas system and includes a shut-off valve.

images.alt: External BBQ gas point with cover closed
images.caption: BBQ point behind exterior panel

images.alt: BBQ connected to external gas point
images.caption: Portable BBQ connected to gas point

safety_notes: Close BBQ point valve when not in use
Check for gas leaks using soapy water
Use only in well-ventilated outdoor areas
Never use BBQ indoors or in enclosed spaces
Turn off gas at bottle when leaving vehicle unattended

systems.name: Outdoor TV Point
systems.description: An external 12V power and aerial socket allows a TV to be set up outside under the awning. Perfect for watching sport or evening entertainment outdoors in good weather.

images.caption: Outdoor TV socket with 12V and aerial connections

images.alt: TV set up outside under awning
images.caption: Outdoor TV setup for evening viewing

safety_notes: Protect TV from rain and moisture
Do not leave TV outside unattended
Monitor battery level when using on 12V
Secure cables to prevent trip hazards

systems.name: Gas Storage (2×13kg Cylinders)
systems.description: The gas locker houses two 13kg propane or butane cylinders, providing fuel for heating, cooking, fridge, and the BBQ point. A changeover valve or regulator allows switching between bottles.

images.caption: Gas locker with dual 13kg bottle capacity
Regulator allows switching between bottles
Pigtail hose connects bottle to regulator

safety_notes: Turn off all gas appliances before changing bottles
Check connections for leaks using soapy water
Ensure gas locker drain hole is clear
Store spare cylinders upright and secured
Turn off gas at bottle when vehicle is unattended
Never smoke or use naked flames near gas locker

systems.name: Cassette Toilet
systems.description: The cassette toilet features a removable waste cassette accessed via an external door. The cassette is emptied at designated disposal points. Flush water comes from the fresh water tank.

images.caption: Cassette toilet with electric flush
External door for cassette removal
Slide cassette out for emptying

safety_notes: Use only approved toilet chemicals
Empty cassette at designated disposal points only
Do not overfill cassette - check indicator
Wear gloves when handling cassette
Rinse cassette after emptying
Keep cassette blade closed when transporting

systems.name: Fresh Water Tank External Access
systems.description: The fresh water tank is filled via an external filler cap, making it easy to connect a hose without entering the vehicle. Tank level is displayed on the control panel inside.

images.caption: Fresh water filler on exterior panel

images.alt: Control panel showing water tank level
images.caption: Monitor tank level on control panel

safety_notes: Use only drinking water approved hoses
Do not overfill - stop when indicator shows full
Secure filler cap after filling
Drain tank before freezing conditions
Flush system if water has been standing

systems.name: Alarm System
systems.description: The motorhome alarm system monitors doors and windows for intrusion. When armed, it will sound an alert if entry points are opened. The system is controlled by a key fob or internal panel.

images.caption: Alarm status panel inside vehicle
Key fob for arming/disarming alarm
Sensors on doors and windows

safety_notes: Arm alarm when leaving vehicle unattended
Keep spare key fob battery available
Test alarm periodically
Know how to silence false alarms
Register alarm with local police if possible

systems.name: Vehicle Tracker
systems.description: A GPS vehicle tracker is fitted for theft recovery and location monitoring. The tracker allows the vehicle location to be checked via a smartphone app or web portal. Some insurance policies require a tracker.

images.alt: Tracker smartphone app showing vehicle location
images.caption: View vehicle location on phone app
Tracker unit is discretely installed

safety_notes: Keep tracker subscription active
Know how to access tracker app/portal
Report theft to police and tracker company immediately
Keep tracker installation location confidential
Test tracker function periodically

systems.name: 5G Internet System
systems.description: The 5G mobile internet system provides high-speed connectivity for streaming, browsing, and remote working while on the road. The router creates a WiFi hotspot for all devices in the vehicle.

images.caption: 5G router with WiFi hotspot
External antenna for better signal

safety_notes: Check data allowance to avoid excess charges
Signal strength varies by location
Router draws power from leisure battery
Secure WiFi network with strong password
4G fallback available in areas without 5G

systems.name: Control Panel
systems.description: The main control panel displays battery status, water tank levels, and allows control of the water pump and other systems. Some vehicles have a CBE or Schaudt panel.

images.caption: Control panel showing system status

safety_notes: Monitor battery level to avoid running flat
Check tank levels before departing
Contact dealer if error codes appear
Refer to manual for specific functions

systems.name: Mains Battery Charger
systems.description: When connected to mains hook-up, the built-in charger automatically charges the leisure battery. This ensures batteries are maintained and ready for off-grid use.

images.caption: Charger activates on mains connection
Connect mains cable here

safety_notes: Always connect to vehicle first, then mains supply
Disconnect mains first when leaving
Use only approved camping mains cables
Check cable condition regularly
Do not use damaged or wet cables

systems.name: Driving & Vehicle
systems.description: Based on Fiat Ducato chassis with safety features including ABS, driver/passenger airbags, and ESP. Maximum permitted weight and payload limits must be observed. Regular servicing is essential.

images.alt: Front view of the Bürstner Ixeo I 744
images.caption: Bürstner Ixeo I 744 - front exterior view
Cab area showing Fiat Ducato dashboard and controls

images.alt: Rear view showing bike rack and reversing camera
images.caption: Rear view - check camera and clearance before reversing

safety_notes: Check all items are secured before driving
Never exceed the maximum permitted weight
Ensure roof vents and windows are closed before moving
Check mirrors and cameras are properly adjusted
Passengers must use seatbelts while driving
Know your vehicle height for bridges and barriers

systems.name: Common Problems & Troubleshooting
systems.description: Quick reference for common issues including electrical faults, water system problems, heating failures, and general maintenance concerns.

images.alt: 12V fuse box location inside the Ixeo I 744
images.caption: Fuse box location - check here for electrical faults

images.alt: Main control panel showing system status
images.caption: Main control panel - check for error indicators
Water pump - listen for operation when troubleshooting

safety_notes: For gas-related issues, contact a qualified technician
Do not attempt repairs beyond your skill level
Keep emergency contact numbers readily available
If in doubt about safety, seek professional help
